text: Lesson 1: Finding Things in the World
Match the different sources of information.
Match the tools to the image
Find out about a sustainable invention. Which scientist contributed the most to its development? Write a short response about why this invention is important.
Upload a picture of a sustainable invention that you described in the Open Response mini-game
Pick a country from the globe.
Find and describe a sustainable practice in this country that you can implement on your own.
Lesson 2: Why Does the Dandelion Look Like a Parachute?
Pick an object around you. Complete the sentence:
Observing (your object), I found out that ‚Ä¶
Take a walk and on that walk, take a picture of a dandelion
What is not a human sense?
Observation is the main method of learning about nature
What is not a type of natural scientist?
Astronomers use what kind of building to observe objects through powerful telescopes?
Order the steps to designing an experiment
Think about the stages of observation
Write down or draw the observation
Identify a man-made object that resembles something from nature. Upload a photo of that object.
Design an experiment connected to analyzing something in nature. Write down the plan for conducting it.
Take a picture of what you are planning to analyze in your experiment
What is the first step in the experiment?
Lying in bed you notice that you get cold every time your brother opens the door. This is most closely associated with which step in conducting an experiment:
What is the last step in the experiment?
Your best ‚Äúeducated guess‚Äù of what the answer to your question will be
Whatever the teacher tells you is the truth.
Order the steps to conducting an experiment
Pick a flower and leave it in water. Now, put something in the water such as food coloring.
Watch how the flower reacts. How is this similar to when water has other materials in it?
Lesson 4: What Are the Secrets of Plants?
What is your favorite plant? Take a picture.
In which part of the plant is this obtained?
How does this affect the surrounding ecosystem?
Find a plant in the real world. Take a picture of the plant.
Note how the plant acquires its food. What are the factors in the plant cycle present?
How does this plant (cactus) survive in a place without water?
Take a picture of a habitat in which your favorite plant grows.
Find two plants in different habitats. Take pictures of the plants.
How do the plants differ in their habitats?
Lesson 6: Who Hatched From the Egg?
1. What makes a fish unique from other vertebrates?
Pass oxygenated water through their gills
The bones of the fish make up their skeleton
Fish can survive outside of their habitat
2. Which one of these is not an insect?
3. Which one of the following is a bird?
4. What is the smallest group of vertebrates?
What type of vertebrate is this - Amphibians vs Mammals?
Which group of animals lays eggs? Can you take a picture of one animal that
Many animals hatch from eggs. The egg shells are of no use after the animals are hatched. Or are they?
Research and describe two different animals and how we could use their eggshells for different purposes.
Lesson 7: Who Plays Hide and Seek?
Which of these are not methods of animals protecting themselves from predators?
Running towards the predator to talk it out
Having thick shells, sharp needles, and bright colors
How has a turtle adapted to its environment?
Different shaped feet, mouth, and shells
Can animals live both underground and above ground?
Which of these is not necessary for animal survival?
Can you name three underground animals? Explain how these animals
have adapted to their surroundings and why their current environment is best.
What type of vertebrate is this - Reptiles vs Birds?
Animals can live above ground, underground, in water, on the sand, etc. Animals adapt to these different conditions in their environment through physical and mental adaptations.
Find an animal around you and identify its distinct physical features. Through the appearance of the animal, can you determine where the animal lives, moves and eats?
How do crocodiles prepare for the summer? Specifically, when there is drought?
What order are the seasons in? Start from January
To look for resources, mainly food and nesting locations
Birds are generally nomadic creatures and don‚Äôt stay in one place
Do all birds follow the same migration patterns?
Why do bears prepare for the winter?
Bears cannot find food in this climate
Spend quality time with their loved ones
What should you not do when taking a trip out in nature?
Leave a trace on the nature trail to mark your accomplishment
Why do animals need to be protected?
There are no space in museums for extinct animals
Animals are fun to look at
Animals fit into the food chain and extinction disrupts natural order
Take a picture of an animal that needs to be protected more
Animals are all part of a food chain. There are predators and there are prey. However, sometimes humans enter and disrupt the food chain. They poach and hunt animals.
How do animals elude predators and humans with their body shape, coloring, and other physical features?
List many of the functions of the human skeleton
Order by the number of bones a human has at each stage
The human skeleton provides support from our body. Go outside and find an animal to do research on.
Observe the animal‚Äôs skeleton and describe how it helps the animal sustain their habits.
List many of the functions of our muscles
Every muscle in the human body has a different shape
What are the benefits of regular exercise?
What is the largest muscle in the human body?
What are the different types of muscle?
How do the flexor and extensor muscles work together?
bend and straighten the body's joints to produce motion

Smiling makes us happy. Give a present to a loved one to make them smile. But this shouldn‚Äôt be any present. Make sure the present you give them is a sustainable invention that they can use in many scenarios.
Do you have perfect posture? If yes, tell me the reasons you do. If not, what should you do to improve your posture?
A heavier backpack on a child has no effect on posture
Why is the right posture important?
What does bad posture do to your spine?
Puts unnecessary pressure on your spine
Evenly distributes the weight on your spine
Keeps you comfortable and reduces injury risk
Allows you to maintain a full range of motion
How does your posture change over time?
Your posture will change depending on how you maintain it
As you grow old, your spine will form a permanent curve
Over time, your spine will become straighter due to stronger muscles
Is this an example of good posture or bad posture?

Your posture is the habitual position of your body when it is standing, sitting, or walking. The weight of any extra items such as your backpack can affect your posture. Look inside your backpack and see what you can reduce, reuse, recycle, and digitalize. Let‚Äôs try to make your backpack lighter and save the planet by using less paper!
Lesson 12: What Are Bacteria Afraid Of?
What are some unique ways or methods you stay clean? Explain them. If you don‚Äôt have any, research some and explain.
Take a picture or record a video of a good cleaning practice
Washing your hands with soap and water can get rid of millions of microbes
How do we take care of our body throughout the day?
Wash our skin and face often
Wash our hands with soap and water
Wipe off sweat from our body
What is one way scientists can study microbes?
Take a picture of the object containing microbes with their phone Camera üì∑
Use scientific instruments such as microscopes
Scientists are not able to study microbes to their extremely miniscule size
How much bacteria do we approximately have?
Does this activity help with cleanliness or uncleanliness?
Kim ate garlic bread for lunch and he brushed his teeth after
Emily buys an exfoliator and scrub at the store as she wants to exfoliate once a week
Marcos‚Äô friends give him deodorant and tell him to use it
Rachel feels like she should take a shower
Johnny is sweaty and tired of playing basketball so he heads to his class right after
Melissa uses the same sponge for weeks and doesn‚Äôt understand why it smells
Richard‚Äôs bedsheets start smelling funky so he sprays air freshener

Your body is very complex and valuable, and to stay healthy we must take care of it. We want to sustain our health for as long as possible and make sure we don‚Äôt infect others. Describe how you wash your hands.
Lesson 13: Why Do My Teeth Hurt?

Many animals have teeth, some small, some sharp, some large, some dull, but they all serve a purpose. However, teeth can serve more than one purpose and animal teeth can be used for many different functions. List some sustainable functions that (animal/human) teeth can be used for other than eating.
Take a picture of two different foods and explain why one food is better for your teeth than the other
Are these behaviors helpful or harmful to your teeth' health?
Flossing your teeth once a day
Eating chips rather than sugary snacks
Look for flavor instead of fluoride in your toothpaste
Order these animals by the amount of teeth they have
Humans have many teeth but only one set of teeth. Good oral hygiene then is very important and you should properly care for your teeth every day and night.

One form of taking care of your teeth is eating good food that doesn‚Äôt rot your teeth. Keep track of all the food and drinks you consume in a day and label each one with whether it is teeth-healthy or teeth-unhealthy.
Lesson 14: What Are the Properties of Air?
Which is not going to help reduce our carbon footprint?
What gas is increasing in large amounts due to human activities?
Name of the gas the plants take in
Which one of these does not add CO2 to the atmosphere?
While being cooled down, the air _______:
Why don‚Äôt animals get cold in winter?
Take three pictures of different thing that pollute the air in your city
Sort the causes of air pollution
Understand that all plants and animals need air. Describe what happens when a plant has limited air.
Lesson 15: Where to Build a Factory?
What happens to the temperature if more greenhouse gasses are released into the atmosphere?
Which of the following activities contributes the most to carbon emissions globally?
Increased carbon dioxide may cause global warming by
allowing more sunlight into the atmosphere.
reducing the amount of oxygen in the air.
trapping more heat in the atmosphere.
Which is a natural source of greenhouse gasses?
The warming of a planet due to trapped radiation.
The cooling of Earth due to air pollution.
The heating of a solid, such as a rock.
Make a plan of how you will avoid polluting the air
Upload a picture of the factory that causes the most pollution in the area.
Refill a water bottle with water from home instead of buying a new one
Update your computer rather than throwing it out and getting a replacement
Ditch plastic bags and choose reusable, environmentally-friendly bags instead
Separating cardboard to put in the recycling facility
Look for items that you can reuse instead of buying
Find a factory or a place similar to a factory near your home. Do your best to research the ecosystem present there before the factory and after the factory.
Take note of the factors that caused these changes. Describe a plan to revert or mitigate some of the damages.
Lesson 16: What Do We Know About Water?
Which is not a major source of water pollution in the modern world?
Harmful substances enter a water supply
Industries dispose of waste safely and correctly.
There is nothing we can do to stop water pollution.
We can prevent water pollution by:
How many forms does water come in?
Sweat from our bodies on hot days
Warm rain but not cold snow or sleet
Gas that we use in furnaces or ovens
Any form of water that falls from the sky
Which example is a form of precipitation?
the movement of water on, above, or below the surface of the Earth
Evaporation happens when the sun ___________ water and turns it into vapor.
Water in its gas form is called __________,
Describe the picture. What do you think should be changed?
Put the oceans from the smallest to the largest.
Arctic, Southern, Indian, Atlantic and Pacific.
Draw a water cycle and take a picture of it.

Research where the water in your household comes from. Trace it back to the original source. Visit the source and find out the water purification method used. Reflect on the method and offer your own critiques and compliments.
Lesson 17: What Does a Person Need?
How do people use natural resources to create energy? Name one good (sustainable) way the energy is created and one bad (unsustainable) way?
What is NOT a sustainable practice?
What is the term used to describe objects that are being washed and used again?
What is the term used to describe objects that are being made into new materials?
place where trash is piled up
Take three pictures of the ways you take care of the environment
There are many natural resources present on Earth but man has mismanaged many of them. Nature is our friend and we must protect her.
Take a picture of a natural resource in your neighborhood. Learn about its past, present, and future. Describe the implications of its current usage.
Lesson 18: The Sun and its Influence on Earth
Find out and describe how the Moon influences the oceans
Take photos of 5 solar panels in your city
Solar Energy is not a renewable energy source.
Solar Energy is created by the ________.
Disadvantages of using Solar Energy include:
Advantages of using solar energy include:
Damaging your eyes can be caused by this
Solar Cells convert light into electricity.
Plants need _________________ to do photosynthesis just like solar panels?
Why are fossil fuels more widely used than solar energy?
Solar energy is harder to find.
The sun's energy can never be harnessed.
Its gravity holds all the planets in place
Takes about a month to revolve the Earth

The sun provides light and heats the Earth. However, like anything, nature should be kept in balance. There are balancing factors to neutralize the Sun‚Äôs tremendous amount of heat. Explain why we need sunscreen and explain how Earth‚Äôs ecosystems have their own built-in sunscreen.
Lesson 19: Who Are the Sun‚Äôs Friends?
Research and describe the origin of the names of 3 planets of your choice.
Put the planets in order from the closest to the Sun to the furthest
1. Most of Earth's energy comes from‚Ä¶
2. The Earth acts like a greenhouse that catches and traps heat from the sun.
3. _______________ is an increase in global temperatures believed to be caused in part by the greenhouse effect.
4. _______________ is a change in global and regional climate patterns attributed to an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels.
There are many other planets in our solar system and they orbit the Sun. Life is only sustainable on planet Earth.
Make a case for another planet that might be able to support life. Formulate some changes that will make this planet a better place for life.
Once done, draw our solar system with all its planets orbiting the Sun and try your best to show differences in size and shape.
Put the planets in order from the smallest to the largest
Which is the closest planet to the Sun?
Which planet do the moons Oberton and Titania belong to?
The largest volcano in the solar system is called Olympus Mons. Where is it?
What is the Great Red Spot on Jupiter?
What is the Sun mainly made from?
Which of these planets is the smallest?
How many moons does Mars have?
What are comets mostly made of?
Which of these best describes the atmosphere surrounding Venus?
Space exploration is very important in our day and age. We are on a mission to explore all the other planets.
Find out one planet that we are exploring currently. Then, figure out the method of exploration.
What are the effects of space exploration on our atmosphere? And do you believe the benefits of space exploration negate the cons?
Lesson 21: Why Does Spring Follow Winter?
Record the temperature at 8 am, 1 pm, 6 pm, and 9 pm. What do you notice about the temperature change? Describe your observations.
The calendar is a counting system of time divided into days, months, and years.

Draw the change of a newly planted tree over days, months, and years. For example, you can draw a newly planted tree over the course of many days. Then, draw the change over the course of a few months (seasons changing). Then, draw the change over the course of a few years.
What clock is the most accurate?
Draw a life cycle of a flower
Take a picture of the sunset
Match a picture of a clock to the time it displays
Humans have invented different ways to tell time from the sundial to the water clock.
Take a picture of any household item that shows time. Record and describe the pattern you see.
Find three objects, people, animals in your home that you can describe forces that are acting upon them. For example, gravity is a force that affects humans by pulling them to the center of Earth.
From the Open Response question, take a picture of one of the objects, people, animals you described.
If two children are pulling each other with the same force, what will happen?
The children do not move at all
Only one of them moves while the other one stays still
The bigger child moves the smaller child
If you drop a pear from a building, what will be the main force acting on the pear?
What are the different directions forces can move in?
How can we relate physics to sustainability?
Different gasses and clouds affect the earth‚Äôs temperature
Newton‚Äôs laws of motion are used for recycling
There is less force acting on reusable objects
What subject of physics is being studied as our primary energy source?
Nothing in the world can move until there is a force either pushing or pulling it. Therefore, objects can only move when there is a force applied to them.
Think about the many sustainable energy sources such as wind, solar, and water. How do we use forces to push or pull and generate energy?
Why are objects that are fast bad for the environment? Is it because of the energy required to power them? Do you have any ideas on making them more efficient?
Take a picture of an item you can measure speed with.
Sort the items based on speed
Put these vehicles in order of energy efficiency
The object that moves faster has a higher speed. This means that during the same time, the object with a higher speed will cover a longer distance.
Does high speed have any negative effects on the environment? Explain your answer.
What is a new/different form/mode of transportation that‚Äôs been added to your neighborhood?
Take a picture of a mode of transportation that is more environmentally friendly than other modes available
Order these vehicles from oldest to newest
Which one of these animals is the saiga slower than?
How can we be more environmentally friendly with fast vehicles?
Turn the engine off when not in use
Open the windows instead of AC
Can we use speed to make sustainable energy?
Use the speed of animals to generate energy like a hamster spinning on a wheel
The speed of animals cannot be used to generate energy
Use the speed of animals to generate energy like sitting on a cheetah running back and forth
Although using animals for energy can be done, it is unethical and shouldn‚Äôt be done
How many legs are needed to run fast?
2, the less legs the faster you can run
4, the more legs the faster you can run
0, wings can help you fly faster than run
It does not depend on the amount of legs
The Kazakhstan eagle might seem clumsy and immobile first, but it is indeed swift. Although the animal might seem loud, that doesn‚Äôt take away from its speed.
Go outside and examine the many cars on the road. Record a video of the cars passing by.
Examine the noise level produced by each car in the video you took and do a mini-experiment. Are the louder cars worse to the environment? Why?
Lesson 26: How Much Does an Elephant Weigh?
Take a picture of a heavy object. How can we make this object lighter and more sustainable?

Find one of the heaviest objects in your house. What is it made out of? Try to identify the composition of materials and then label each material as either environmentally friendly or not. Try your best!
Put these objects in order from lightest to heaviest
Mass is hard to estimate when it comes to visually objects that we‚Äôve never seen before. How heavy do you think a whale‚Äôs tongue is?
Heavier than an elephant, bike, and a human combined
Heavier than a bike and a human
Not heavier than any of these listed above
If two objects are hit with the same force, which object will roll faster?
The object that has a more rectangular shape
None of the objects because they are hit with the same force
Do different countries have different measurement standards?
Which of these do not belong?
When it comes to making everyday objects, we should _____.
Use less mass in order to save materials and be sustainable
Use more mass in order to use more materials and be sustainable
Use less mass because it is cheaper and spending less is sustainable
Use less mass because spending less and saving materials are both sustainable
Objects of different mass will react differently when the same force is applied to them. The object with more mass will gain less speed than the object with less mass.
Ask a friend to help you in this activity. Take turns applying similar forces to different objects.

Now that you understand how this works, we‚Äôll compare different energy sources to each other. Some energy sources need less area and less mass to be effective than others. Research and describe the different energy sources and their requirements in terms of area and mass.
Lesson 27: How to Get to Emerald City?
Take a picture of the most environmentally-friendly light source in your home.
Think properly, this is a trick question!

If you didn‚Äôt get the Camera üì∑ question, the most environmentally-friendly light source is the Sun because it is natural. However, your home can still save more energy. Find a light source in your home and think about how you can save more energy.
Order these light sources From least sustainable to most sustainable

Light is a form of energy that allows living organisms to see the world around them. Our very own sun emits mass amounts of energy through rays of light. And everyday glass bottles are great at catching the sun‚Äôs rays. One might say they are too great because it can even cause a fire if they catch too much sunlight.

Grab a friend and head outside. Each time you spot a glass bottle before your friend you get a point. Each time you spot a recycle bin for said glass bottle you get a point. Keep track of the points and make sure you recycle all the glass bottles.
Lesson 28: Where Did the Light Go?
Take a picture of an opaque and transparent object side to side.
What happens to rays of light when they meet another object? Does it go in a straight line or not? What sustainable benefits can we use these for?
You are out on your balcony on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. The sun is shining and hitting the glass. How can we use this sustainably?
Use materials such as aluminum foil, etc. to cook with the sunlight
Stand under the sunlight to naturally tan rather than artificially tan
Grow a plant with the sunlight and then use the seeds from that plant to grow more
Which of these objects are translucent?
Which of these objects are translucent?
Which of these objects are opaque?

A ray of sunlight moves in a straight line and changes its behavior as it hits different objects. Some objects such as metal, wood, and stone absorb most of the light and do not allow it to pass through them.
Describe what would happen if you left a crayon under the sun.
Take a picture of a natural source of sound
What is the difference between natural sources of sound and artificial sources of sound? How can we use natural sources of sound for sustainable behaviors?
What is a sustainable source of sound?
A rooster making noise to wake you up in the morning
A speaker making louder, disruptive noise for everyone to hear
A car revving its engine releasing gasses into the air
Is sound a form of energy?
Forward and backward movement called oscillation and the vibrations that propagate through the air are these sound waves.
From a speaker located deep inside Earth‚Äôs core
The Earth‚Äôs gravitational pulls waves to the center and pushes them out loudly
Loud noise from a construction site
The sounds you hear tell you what is going on. Nowadays, there is a massive amount of sound pollution.

Did you know that shouting in someone‚Äôs ear can lead to deafness? Loud sounds near the eardrums over time can damage your hearing as well. We have to eliminate sound pollution and it can start from inside the household.
Identify loud noises and record their source, explanation, and loudness relative to each other in a notepad. Explain which sounds could be eliminated or reduced.
Lesson 30: How Do We Hear Sounds?
Take a picture of any device used to hear sounds
Why are the theater, performance center, and stadiums arranged in that way? Does this help with sound production? What are your thoughts?
We all hear sounds differently. Animals, plants, and humans can all hear sounds.

Go outside and find three different animals. Take note of how they react to sound. Try and understand why they hear sounds in the manner that they do. Is it an evolutionary process? How does it help them maintain their lifestyle?
What is the hottest part of Kazakhstan? Explain why
Take a picture of the thermometer in your house.
Get a thermometer. Visit a nearby park and find three different plants.
Record the temperature of the leaves of the plants. Record the temperature of the soil of the plants. Identify any patterns for these plants in accordance with the temperature and their growth.
Describe why different plants, animals, and humans live in different temperatures.
Lesson 32: Where Does Frost Hide During the Summer?
Ask your parents about summer and winter temperatures when they were kids. Compare it to the temperatures right now. Do you notice any differences?
Take a picture of things that help us keep cooler in summer
Sort the animals based on their environment
What is likely to result from global warming?
When weather patterns change over a long period of time, we call it ___
What is the main gas that is trapping more heat close to the Earth, acting like a blanket?
Increasing quantities of CO2 (Carbon Dioxide) in the atmosphere will cause air temperatures to be _____.
Climate change causes extreme weather conditions such as:
The amount of carbon dioxide CO2 in the atmosphere is decreasing.
Which human activity contributes the MOST carbon dioxide to the atmosphere?
Possible human solutions for limiting global warming and climate change are‚Ä¶
Removing carbon from fossil fuel emissions
Causes sea levels to rise because it adds water to the ocean.
Does not cause sea levels to rise because the water fills the space left by the melted sea ice.
Why does cutting down trees increase global warming?
Trees provide shade which counteracts global warming
Trees absorbs the sun's energy without radiating back into the atmosphere
Trees drain greenhouse gasses like methane from soil

When people think of warmth, they think of sunny, summer days. Or you could think about cold, winter days with the heater on. Regardless, heat is a form of energy that is always being generated. However, generating heat in the winter can cost energy and leave a massive carbon footprint. Generating cold in the summer can cost energy and leave a massive carbon footprint.

Go outside to your nearest park. Understand how many animals keep cool in the summer or keep warm in the winter depending on the climate. Describe how changes to our body could help us keep climate in control similarly to them.
Take pictures of the devices where magnets are used
Are magnets environmentally friendly? Explain your answer.
A magnet is a material that attracts wood, rubber, and glass.
A magnet is a material that attracts certain metals, such as iron, nickel, and cobalt.
A magnet has two poles, the north pole and the south pole.
A magnet has two poles, the west pole and the east pole
‚Äã‚Äã      3. Magnets attract all types of metals.
4. Magnet poles that are different will ________ one another.
Magnets can pull through liquids, solids, and gasses.
Magnets will not attract items when blocked by liquids, solids, and gasses.
6. Which toy would a magnet attract?

Magnets are objects that can attract or repel other objects. They are present and are found around the world. There are many objects around the household that are magnetic that you may not know about.
Find a magnet and test its magnetism on different objects around the house. Record your observations. Now that you‚Äôve done this, describe different ways you could use magnets.
Go to a library and pick a book you would like to read this summer. Take a picture of it
What sustainable activities are you going to do this summer?
Staying hydrated with a reusable bottle
Closing the shades to keep the room cooler
Rank transport from the most sustainable to the least sustainable.
Your long summer vacation is about to begin. You‚Äôve done a lot of sustainability research during the year, but there‚Äôs more. This time you will create a sustainability exercise for your parents.

Look through all the previous lessons and gather some ideas. Use only one lesson as your main inspiration but you can take ideas from all of them. Foster your own Mastery üéì challenge and make sure that at the end of the exercise your parents learn something. Take pictures, videos, and notes, and record all your observations. Great job scientists!
